0.user_question: Find the remainder when $(5x + 9)^{611} + (x + 5)^{11} + (x - 1)^{11} + 3x^2 + 1$ is divided by $x + 2.$

direct_answer.text: By the Remainder Theorem, the remainder obtained upon dividing any polynomial f(x) into x + k as denominator equals value of function evaluated at negative (-k). Here, since our divisor here is \(x + 2\), therefore required term/remainder would equal evaluation of entire equation when x=-2. Substituting x=-2 throughout we get : \left( {5*(-2)+9} \right)^{(})^{}\text{{}}^{}+(\!\!{-2+5})^{11}+\!(^{-2}-1)^{11}+3({-2)}^{2}+1=\\ =\quad (-\!1)^{\text{}}^{\text{}}\,\cdot\,1^{11}\,\cdot\,\,(\!\!{1})^{11}\,\cdot\,\,6\,\cdot \,1+\,(3)\,\cdot\,(6)^{11}\,+3(-4)\,+1 \\ =\quad -\,\,\cdot\,1\,^\ast\,1&\,\,\,1&\,\,\times \,6&\,+\,3\,\cdot\,6^{11}\,\,\times\,1\,\,\times\,6\;+\;-12 +\,1 \\ =~~~

0.user_question: Find the remainder when $(5x + 9)^{611} + (x + 5)^{11} + (x - 1)^{11} + 3x^2 + 1$ is divided by $x + 2.$

1.subquestion: According to Remainder Theorem, substitute $x=-2$ as follows:\n$$p(-2)=((-2)+9)^{611}+((-2)+5)^{11}+((-2)-1)^{11}+3(-2)^2+1.$$

0.user_question: Find the remainder when $(5x + 9)^{611} + (x + 5)^{11} + (x - 1)^{11} + 3x^2 + 1$ is divided by $x + 2.$

1.subquestion: By using Fermat's Little Theorem or its generalization, Remainder theorem, evaluate the expression at $x=-2,$ which corresponds to applying polynomial division without actually performing long division. This evaluates as follows:\n$\begin{aligned}(&5(-2)+9)^{611}+((-2)+5)^{11}+((-2)-1)^{11}\\+ &3(-2)^2+(1)\\\\=& \\&= 2^{611}+3^9+\;{-3}^{11}\;\;+\;12\;+\;1\\&\equiv \;0

subanswer.text: Applying polynomials modulo their divisor yields \[\begin{array}{ccccc}-9^{611}&++&-+&+&-\end{array}\] As none of those exponents divide 611 any more than they directly divide themselves, taking remainders upon them after reducing every exponent downwards shows no change so nothing else happens but reduction upward giving $$\begin{array}{c} &&&& 611\\ &\,\Downarrow\,\\[-5pt]\underline{!}_{-3}\,\,\,&&!\qquad2^{-6},\quad9^{-6}, \quad {-3}^{-6}\,\\ &\,\Downarrow\,\,,\\[-5pt]\hline  0\end{array}$$So our final evaluation under modular arithmetic leads us straight to zero since $$FLT:(-2)^{-k}\equiv ((-2)(-1))^{-k}\equiv (-1)^{-k}$$so either case whereby positive values don’t matter because everything evaluated just becomes itself squared until raised enough times to force negative powers disappear entirely leaving only integer constants like squares rather having anything left over once reduced further still if possible... Thus concluding hereafter w/o doing actual division work otherwise required besides showing above via example how simplification works priorhand." Answer 5.1: Using synthetic division or direct substitution ($x=2$) due to factor theorem, $(\text{remainder})=(5*2+9)^{611}+(2+5)^{11}+(2-1)^{11}+3*(2)^2+1$, resulting in \(\boxed{0}\) as the remainder. The answer is \(0\).

1.subquestion: Assume the simplest case where only polynomial long division could apply; how would you approach finding what remains upon division by \(x + 2\)?

subanswer.text: To perform such polynomial long division, arrange your dividend (expression being divided) and divisor (\(x+2\)). Divide the leading term of the dividend by the leading coefficient of the divisor's highest degree term to determine the quotient’s leading term. Multiply the entire divisor by this new term and subtract the resulting expression from the initial dividend, bringing down any subsequent terms as needed until completion. This process yields the remainder over the original divisor which indicates the remainders obtained during complex numerical examples detailed above require stepwise explanation rooted within
